HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 17, 1924

FRESHMAN BREAKS
ARM POLE-VAULTING
Falling heavily on his forearm against the base of a
standard, while vaulting at
Homewood Field, Tuesday
afternoon, Taylor Pierce, '28,
sustained a. compound fracture of the left arm. Dr.
Abercrombie rendered first
aid, and Pierce was, hurried
to the Johns Hopkins Hospital. He was able to return
home after ,treatment, but
was forced to remain away
from classes the following
day. Pierce had been showing good form as a vaulter in
the early fall practice.

DAVIS WINS HOPKINS STRAW
BALLOT; LaFOLLETTE
IS CLOSE SECOND
Official Returns Are: Davis, 126; LaFollette, 125; Coolidge, 98; Faculty Gives Comment

POETRY FANS JAM
C. E. LECTURE HALL
Poetry and two poets
proved as strong a drawing
card as a first-rate football
game on Tuesday, when
Walter De La Mare lectured
on Keats in the Civil Engineering Hall. The lecture
hall was besieged with a
crowd as eager to secure
places as fans striving for
seats to an Army-Navy
game. Window sills, radiators, platforms and the C. E.
Hall piano served as seats.
Rabid poetry fans climbed
rainspouts and chimneys to
secure precarious points of
vantage to hear Mr. De La
Mare speak.

John W. Davis won the Hopkin's straw ballot, Robert La Follette finished a close second, while
President Calvin Coolidge pulled
under the wire a bad third. The
News-Letter held the vote on
Wednesday, Thursday and Friday of the week of October fifth.
The diversity of political opinion
at Homewood was shown, not
only by the split vote, but by the
expressions and comments on the
vote given by various professors
of the University.

be taken as an indorsement of its views
by the "News-Letter," which invites the
freest discussion of matters of general

ISIDORE O'BRIEN.
Class since death took from among us on August the eighteenth our
Honorary President, J. Elliott Gilpin, Ph. D.,
And, whereas, we had come to love and admire Dr. Gilpin during our association with him throughout our Freshman, Sophomore
and Junior years at the University,
And, whereas, for these three years as Honorary President of
our Class-, by his high, noble and inspiring character; by his willingness always to give advice; by his unselfish devotion to the welfare
of our Class ; won the true friendship and admiration of every individual member of the Class of 1925,
And, whereas, we individually and collectively are genuinely
grieved by the loss of one so endeared to us,
Therefore, Be it resolved, That, we, the Class of 1925 do feel
a profoundly deep sorrow and loss in the death of our Honorary President, Dr. J. Elliott Gilpin; and our sympathy is with all who are,
by his death, bereaved of a patient teacher, a willing adviser, and a
true friend.
The Senior Class in their first meeting of the year passed this
resolution to express their sorrow at the loss of a consistently helpful advisor and friend. The resolution, indicative of the feeling of
bereavement of the entire undergraduate body, was taken when I'it.
painful duty of selecting a new honorary president brought home fut
the first time to the Class as an articulate body the void left by Dr.
Gilpin's death.

SUMMER RESEARCH GROUP
ATTENDED BY "Y" MEN
Last spring a body of men decided to have an Industrial Research Group in Baltimore. Facts
concerning this group's activities
are now in report form.
The plan was for "students of
educational institutions in several
different states" under the super
vision of the Intercollegiate Department of the Baltimore Y. M.
C. A. and with co-operation oh
several religious organizations of
Baltimore, to hold an industrial
research for six 'weeks, in this
city. The students on coming to
Baltimore were to find employment and live among working people. They met three times each
week to hear speakers and discuss
their experience.
The members of the Group had
two purposes in mind. They were
to gain from actual experience a
knowledge of the industrial situation and also whether Christian
principles can be successfully applied in the business world. Two
Hopkins students, Karl Miller and
Alfred McKay, took part in this
research. They have interesting
experiences to relate. Dr. Broadus
Mitchell, who is connected with
the Political Economy Department at Hopkins, was one of the
prominent men who addressed the
group. His subject was "The History of the Labor Movement in
the U. S. and Great Britain." The general opinion of the
members of the group was that
Christian principles are not followed in industry but if these
principles should be .followed, a
great change for the better would
result in business. Other solutions
were that the greatest hope we
have from industrial reorganization is through the efforts of organized labor. Organized labor
ought to have political ower
through a political power.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 17, 1924

FRESHMAN BREAKS
ARM POLE-VAULTING
Falling heavily on his forearm against the base of a
standard, while vaulting at
Homewood Field, Tuesday
afternoon, Taylor Pierce, '28,
sustained a. compound fracture of the left arm. Dr.
Abercrombie rendered first
aid, and Pierce was, hurried
to the Johns Hopkins Hospital. He was able to return
home after ,treatment, but
was forced to remain away
from classes the following
day. Pierce had been showing good form as a vaulter in
the early fall practice.

DAVIS WINS HOPKINS STRAW
BALLOT; LaFOLLETTE
IS CLOSE SECOND
Official Returns Are: Davis, 126; LaFollette, 125; Coolidge, 98; Faculty Gives Comment

POETRY FANS JAM
C. E. LECTURE HALL
Poetry and two poets
proved as strong a drawing
card as a first-rate football
game on Tuesday, when
Walter De La Mare lectured
on Keats in the Civil Engineering Hall. The lecture
hall was besieged with a
crowd as eager to secure
places as fans striving for
seats to an Army-Navy
game. Window sills, radiators, platforms and the C. E.
Hall piano served as seats.
Rabid poetry fans climbed
rainspouts and chimneys to
secure precarious points of
vantage to hear Mr. De La
Mare speak.

ISIDORE O'BRIEN.
Class since death took from among us on August the eighteenth our
Honorary President, J. Elliott Gilpin, Ph. D.,
And, whereas, we had come to love and admire Dr. Gilpin during our association with him throughout our Freshman, Sophomore
and Junior years at the University,
And, whereas, for these three years as Honorary President of
our Class-, by his high, noble and inspiring character; by his willingness always to give advice; by his unselfish devotion to the welfare
of our Class ; won the true friendship and admiration of every individual member of the Class of 1925,
And, whereas, we individually and collectively are genuinely
grieved by the loss of one so endeared to us,
Therefore, Be it resolved, That, we, the Class of 1925 do feel
a profoundly deep sorrow and loss in the death of our Honorary President, Dr. J. Elliott Gilpin; and our sympathy is with all who are,
by his death, bereaved of a patient teacher, a willing adviser, and a
true friend.
The Senior Class in their first meeting of the year passed this
resolution to express their sorrow at the loss of a consistently helpful advisor and friend. The resolution, indicative of the feeling of
bereavement of the entire undergraduate body, was taken when I'it.
painful duty of selecting a new honorary president brought home fut
the first time to the Class as an articulate body the void left by Dr.
Gilpin's death.

SUMMER RESEARCH GROUP
ATTENDED BY "Y" MEN
Last spring a body of men decided to have an Industrial Research Group in Baltimore. Facts
concerning this group's activities
are now in report form.
The plan was for "students of
educational institutions in several
different states" under the super
vision of the Intercollegiate Department of the Baltimore Y. M.
C. A. and with co-operation oh
several religious organizations of
Baltimore, to hold an industrial
research for six 'weeks, in this
city. The students on coming to
Baltimore were to find employment and live among working people. They met three times each
week to hear speakers and discuss
their experience.
The members of the Group had
two purposes in mind. They were
to gain from actual experience a
knowledge of the industrial situation and also whether Christian
principles can be successfully applied in the business world. Two
Hopkins students, Karl Miller and
Alfred McKay, took part in this
research. They have interesting
experiences to relate. Dr. Broadus
Mitchell, who is connected with
the Political Economy Department at Hopkins, was one of the
prominent men who addressed the
group. His subject was "The History of the Labor Movement in
the U. S. and Great Britain." The general opinion of the
members of the group was that
Christian principles are not followed in industry but if these
principles should be .followed, a
great change for the better would
result in business. Other solutions
were that the greatest hope we
have from industrial reorganization is through the efforts of organized labor. Organized labor
ought to have political ower
through a political power.

No staff appointments have
been made, since the amount of
work done has not been sufficient
to allow any decisions. The advertising manager will be selected
on a competitive basis, George
Hess, business manager, announced. He will be picked about

be based on the amount of advertising sold plus the interest in
handling the advertising accounts.
The editorial staff will not be
appointed for several weeks; at

turned in sufficient material to
warrant their being on the staff.

pictures and snapshots of members of each class. Alan Gump is

book this year and will be art editor.
